context:
I rescue mine. They are family to me, just like my children.
What I can't understand is, during covid lockdowns people adopted support pets. Then after the lockdown they just got rid of the pets. The pets supported them, then people didn't support something that gave you love and support when it wasn't convenient.
People do not "own" dogs. To most of us they are family.
I‚Äôve had 7 Golden‚Äôs in my lifetime‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.they are the best!!

Dogs are great. What else can you say? My last one was more than family. She was an angel and near-human in her understanding, affection, and loyalty. Losing her was traumatic. Again, dogs are great.
Golden Retrievers are better friends than most humans. I will take one over any politician or relatives in a heart beat.
I love pretty much all dogs.   They are such amazing animals.

My son suffered a severe knee dislocation when returning to his HS sport in 2021, likely due to plandemic lockdown. Our Husky, Athena, normally enjoyed rough play with my son. Instantly, following his injury and later surgery, Athena was very gentle and deferential to my son. She would nuzzle gently on the injured knee, alternately licking and whimpering. She would lay with him for hours during his recovery. How did she know?
Look at me, look at me!!!
We've had Goldens for over 30 years.  Best , sweetest, smart, prettiest, breed on earth..

He is the best dog anyone could hope to ever find, he never makes a mess and follows all commands. I live in the country so he has become my shadow during the day.

My Golden Katie passed away a week before I came home from my last combat tour in Afghanistan. It was devastating. 

A year later my wife and I found our new Golden Abby. She was supposed to be "My dog", but I was called away on duty the night we got her, and by the time I came home 3 weeks later, she was "Mommy's Girl". 

No matter, she along with her Golden sister Tifffany (who's "Daddy's Girl") are wonderful members of our family.

I've had Beagle (Babe), German Shepard (Killer), Golden (Sandspurs Bluewater Honeymist, we called him Spur) and currently a Maltipoo. Bella (Maltipoo) is by far the smartest and most perfect dog for my senior years. She has a huge vocabulary, hand signals and intuitive. The Shepard loved the sliding board and was hilarious to watch. He'd beg to be let off leash and when I did he'd run over and climb the 10 or so ladder steps. I'd tell him to "Get Down" and he'd start down sliding on his claws, jumping and stumbling at the bottom. Run around and climb back up again. :) . I recommend a book called "Water Dog" to anyone wanting to train their dog. People always ask when to start training and answers vary. The correct answer is "When you see that the dog can tell the difference between work and play training can start". Pets depend on you, please don't disappoint them.

I adopted a golden in Hawaii when he was 8 weeks from the Humane Society. After he was an adult, a close friend and neighbor across the street was killed in a car wreck.  'Cody' walked over to their house with me where we found my friends young wife surrounded by friends, sobbing uncontrollably as she sat on the sofa.  How to make her pain stop is all you can think in a time like that.  Then Cody, in a very slow motion, carefully climbed up beside her and in such a soft and loving way, slowly began licking the tears from the grieving young woman's cheek.  She stopped sobbing for the moment and sadly laughed...
